awd_titl_txt: Optimizing Patient Transitions from Hospitals to Skilled Nursing Facilities
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will contribute to the advancement of national health, prosperity and welfare by studying transitions from inpatient hospital units to skilled nursing facilities (SNFs).  SNFs are a promising, cost-effective care alternative to expensive inpatient hospital rehabilitation, but poorly coordinated transitions can lead to poor health outcomes and higher costs via hospital readmissions.  This project develops analytical methods to improve care transitions to SNFs.  The research outcomes will help support guidelines for transfer decisions from hospitals to SNFs and will also be useful in guiding transitions between other hospital units. These guidelines have the potential to reduce cost and save lives. Collaboration with physicians and health services researchers will enable this project to achieve real, beneficial improvements in clinical care. The project seeks to increase the diversity in STEM through outreach, teaching, and dissemination and includes an outreach program to undergraduates from under-represented backgrounds, mentorship of PhD students, and integration of new methods into courses.

This project combines a data-driven approach based on observational studies with a stochastic decision-theoretic approach to determine patient transfer strategies that minimize  readmissions.  The sequential decision-making framework is based on a finite horizon, arm acquiring, and non independent and identically (iid) Restless Multiarmed Bandit (RMAB) problem.  Theoretical and computational methods for the optimal control of arm acquiring and non iid RMABs are active areas of investigation.  Readmission rates are estimated by individual SNF using large datasets from several states.  The project will validate the methods developed via simulation of a large academic hospital and nearby SNFs and use the simulation to analyze policies for allocating patients to SNFs with respect to utilization, readmissions, and other costs of care.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Hospitals want to prevent having to hospitalize patients again after their initial discharge from the hospital. This goal has motivated hospitals to send more patients to skilled nursing facilities (SNFs) after discharge. But to which SNF should a patient be sent? This question is difficult to answer for a number of reasons. First, patients and SNFs have large and meaningful differences. Second, SNF availability can change quickly in unscheduled ways. Third, searching for the “best” SNF demands computational power. This proposal provided a solution to each of these issues in a series of three studies.

In the first study, a large dataset was analyzed consisting of hospital discharges to SNFs of Medicare patients residing in Wisconsin, Iowa, and Illinois. Methods were used to reduce the large number of variables into a fewer number of interpretable variables. The reduced set of patient variables described broad health conditions. The reduced set of SNF variables described the type and level of capacity. Together, these variables were then used to predict risk of rehospitalization and mortality within 60 days of discharge, where significant variation was found in patient outcomes by SNFs. For example, SNFs with substantial off-site services yielded significantly lower adjusted risks of rehospitalization for patients with mental health problems and diabetes-related complications, and lower adjusted risks of mortality for patients with general problems than other SNFs. Therefore, some SNFs are better equipped to handle certain patients over others.

The second study presents a framework to improve care transitions based on the premise established in the first study, that certain SNFs may provide better care for some patients than others. A mathematical model was developed, analyzed, and solved to determine patient transfer decisions that minimize readmissions. This model accounted for patient discharge patterns and SNF capacity availability. Conditions are provided for when an easy-to-use myopic policy, which assigns discharged patients to the SNF with the lowest readmission rate that is available, is optimal. Alternative conditions are also provided for knowing other properties of the optimal policy. Using estimated readmission rates, performance of different policies is compared in a simulation with varying discharge process, readmission rates, and future SNF availability. Situations are identified for when the myopic policy may be beneficial to use and when a proposed transfer heuristic provides a better alternative. Overall, this study can guide transfer decisions from hospital to SNF in order to reduce readmissions.

The third and final study picks up where the second study left off, by considering a more general, and more realistic, version of the problem of finding optimal transfer assignments for patients. The goal is to propose and analyze polices that can handle the complex tradeoff between reducing waiting time for an assignment and reducing readmission rates. The proposed policy is based on relaxing the original model, using a technique known as Linear Programming relaxation. The main result is that we show that this policy is asymptotically optimal. Performance of this policy is compared with other practical policies in an extensive simulation study.

In summary, this proposal provided a principled approach – that combined data analysis, modeling, simulation, and theoretical analyses – to answer an important question in health care: how to assign patients to SNFs after a hospital discharge. Ultimately, this work is expected to improve care and reduce costs for patients who are transferred to a SNF after discharge.
